title: Getting Started
scenario: You just logged into a Linux system. First, let's find out where you are. Use the appropriate command to print your current working directory.
hints: The command you need stands for "Print Working Directory"
It's a 3-letter command that starts with "p"

title: Exploring Directories
scenario: Now that you know where you are, let's see what files and directories are in your current location. List the contents of the current directory.

title: Detailed Listing
scenario: Great! Now let's get more details about the files. Use the long listing format to see file permissions, sizes, and modification dates.
hints: You need to add an option flag to the ls command
The flag for long format is "-l"

title: Reading Files
scenario: You see a file called "welcome.txt" in the directory. Let's read its contents to see what it says.
hints: Use the command that concatenates and displays file contents
The command sounds like a small pet animal

title: Changing Directories
scenario: You notice there's a "documents" directory. Let's navigate into it using the change directory command.

title: Creating Directories
scenario: You need to organize your work. Create a new directory called "projects" in your current location.

title: Creating Files
scenario: Now let's create a new empty file called "notes.txt" in the current directory.
hints: The command is called "touch" because it updates file timestamps
If the file doesn't exist, it creates it

title: Going Up
scenario: You're currently in the documents directory. Use the change directory command to go up one level to the parent directory.
hints: Two dots (..) represent the parent directory
Use cd with ".." to go up one level

title: Removing Files
scenario: You have a file in documents called "notes.txt" that you no longer need. Remove this file using the appropriate command.
hints: The command for removing files starts with "rm"
You need to specify the path to the file

title: Echo Command
scenario: Use the echo command to display the message "Hello, Linux!" to the terminal.
hints: The echo command displays text to the terminal
You can use quotes around the text

title: Finding Files
description: Search for files in the directory
scenario: You need to find all .txt files in the current directory. Use the find command with the -name option.
hints: The find command searches for files
Use . to search in current directory

title: Searching Within Files
description: Use grep to search for text patterns
scenario: Search for the word "Welcome" in the welcome.txt file using the grep command.
hints: The grep command searches for patterns in files

title: Absolute Paths
scenario: Navigate to the /home/user directory using an absolute path (starting from root).
hints: The full path to your home is /home/user

title: Multiple Options
scenario: List all files (including hidden ones) in the current directory with detailed information. Combine the -a and -l options.
hints: Options can be written as -la or -l -a

title: System Information
scenario: Find out your current username using the whoami command, then check the current date and time.
hints: First use whoami to see your username
Then use date to see current date and time
You need to run both commands
